body.head:
Sir Francis Bacon Lord Keeper of the great
Seale of England, his speech to Sir William
Jones Cheife Justice of the Kinges Bench in
Ireland./
body.p:
Sir William Iones The Kinge most excellent Maiesty
being tryle informed of your sufficiencie every way,
hath called you by his writt now returned to the
state and degree of a Sergeant at lawe, but not to
stay there, but being so qualified, to serve him as his
cheife Iustice of his kinge Bench in Ireland, And
therefore, that which I shall say to you must be
applyed, not to your sergeants place, which you take,
but in passage, but to that great place, where you are
to settle, And because I will not spend tyme to the
delay of the busines of causes and hearings, I will lead
you the short iourney by examples, and not the long
by precept./

The place, that you shall serve in hath byn fortunate
to be well served in fewer successions before you doe
but take vnto you the constancy and integrity of Sir
Robert Gardiner, the gravity, temper and discrecion
of Sir James Lee, the quicknes industry and dispatch
of Sir Humfty Winch, the care and affection to the
common wealth, and the prudent and politique
administration of Sir John Denham, and you shall need
no other lessons. They were all Lincolns Inne men,
as you are: you may have knowne then as well in their
beginninge, as in their advancemente. But because
you are not to be their onely Cheife Justice but a
Connsellor of Estate, I will putt you in mynde of the
great worke now in hand, that you may doe accordingly
vnto it./

Ireland is the last ex filiis Europe, nothing hath
come in, and hath byn reclaymed from desolation, and a
desert in many places to population and plantation,
and from salvage and barbarous customes to humanity
and civility. This is the kings worke in theise: It is
his garland of heroicall vertue and felicity denyed to
his progenitors, and reserved to his tymes. The worke
is not yet conducted to perfection, but it is in fayre
advance, and this I will say confidently, That if
God blesse that kingdome with peace and Iustice
no vsurer is so since in seven yeares space to double
his principall with interest and interest, as that
kingdome is within the same tyme to double the rest
and principall thereof, yea and perhapps to treble it,
So as that kingdome which once within theis twenty
yeares wise men were wont to doubt, whether they
should wish it to be in a Poole, is like now almost to
become a garden and a younger sister to great Brittaine,
And therefore you must sett downe with yourself
not onely to be a iust governor, and a good cheife
Iustice, as if it were in England, but vnder the
King and the deputy, you are to be a maister
builder and maister planter and Redimer of
Ireland: To which end I will trouble you at this
tyme but with three directions./

1: The first is, that you have an especiall care of
the three plantacions, That of the North, which is
in part acted, that of wixford, which is now in
distraction, and that of long Efford and Kellam,
which is now in Survey. And take this from mee
That the bane of a plantation is, when the vndertakers
or planters
or planters make such hast to a little Mechanicall
present profitt, as disturbeth the whole frame and
noblenes of the worke for the tyme to come, Therefore
hold them to their covennte and the true ordinances of
a plantation./

2: The second is, That you be carefull of the kinge
Revenue due, and by little and little constitute him a
good -, which hither to is little or none, and
the kinge case -- wilbe hardest, when
every mans land shalbe improved in value with
increase manifold, the king shalbe tyed, to his
drye rent./

3: My last direction, though first in weight is, that
you doe all good indeavors to proceed resolutely and
constantly and yet with due temperance and
equally in matters of Religion, least Ireland
civill be worse to vs then Ireland savage./

After Sir William Jones his speech
My Lord said./

I had forgot one thing, which was this, you may
take exceeding great comfort, that you shall serve
with such a deputy, one that I think is a man
ordeyned of God, to doe great good to that kingdome,
And this I think good to speake vnto you, That the
true temper of a cheife Iustice towards a deputy
is neither servilely to second him, nor factiously
to oppose him./
